Expectation1: Secure packages and confirm successful delivery
Situation1: Requesting a signature upon delivery for moderately valuable items
Situation2: They set aside part of their routine to light a lamp and offer prayers at their home altar.
Story: I glanced at the clock on my delivery van’s dashboard—5:45 p.m. My last stop was just a few blocks away, a package that required a signature. The customer had messaged, asking if I could wait a few extra minutes since they were running late. I knew the company expected me to secure every delivery, especially for items like this, and to get that signature no matter what. But my mind kept drifting to home, to the small altar in my living room. Sunset was approaching, and I hadn’t yet lit the lamp or offered my prayers. Every evening, I set aside this time to honor my faith, to feel grounded and connected. If I waited for the customer, I’d miss the sacred window for my ritual. If I left the package, I’d be breaking company policy and risking my job. My phone buzzed again—the customer was still ten minutes away. I stood on the porch, package in hand, heart pounding, torn between my duty as a delivery person and my devotion as a Hindu.
